article.title: Hauser-Feshbach fission fragment de-excitation with calculated macroscopic-microscopic mass yields

multiple_choice_question.text: Figure 1 shows the three-Gaussian parameterization used to fit experimental mass yields. Why is this parameterization used even though it doesn\'t include shell effects?
choices: Shell effects are negligible in these reactions.
The three-Gaussian fit captures the main features of the mass yields despite its simplicity.
Computational limitations prevent the use of more complex models.
Experimental data on shell effects is insufficient for these reactions.

multiple_choice_question.text: What is the main purpose of using calculated mass yields (Y(A)) instead of experimental ones (Ye(A)) in Hauser-Feshbach statistical decay model calculations?
choices: To improve accuracy compared to experimental measurements.
To explore the impact of using theoretically derived yields on fission observables.
To eliminate uncertainties associated with experimental measurements.

multiple_choice_question.text: According to Table I, what is the most significant difference in prompt fission observables when using different mass yield inputs?

Figure 5 shows the correlation between average total kinetic energy (TKE) and average prompt neutron multiplicity (ν). What does this correlation suggest about the possibility of using a precise ν measurement to constrain the allowed (TKE) values?
choices: A precise measurement of ν could reduce the experimental uncertainty on (TKE) by approximately a factor of 3.
There is no correlation between ν and (TKE), making this method unsuitable.
The correlation is too weak to provide any useful constraints.
This method can accurately determine (TKE) without any uncertainty.
